facts.text: Writ Petition No. 2023 of 1973 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 2023 of 1973. Under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for issue of a Writ in the nature of habeas companypus.

facts.text: Milan Banik is the petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: Milan Banik petitioner was ordered by District Magistrate Burdwan to be detained under section 3 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971  Act 26 of 1971  with a view to prevent him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order.

facts.text: District Magistrate Burdwan ordered detention of petitioner under section 3 of Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971 to prevent acting prejudicial to public order.

anchor.surface_text: Milan Banik petitioner was ordered by District Magistrate Burdwan to be detained under section 3 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971  Act 26 of 1971  with a view to prevent him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order. In pursuance of the detention order, the petitioner was arrested on July 23, 1973.

facts.text: Petitioner arrested on July 23, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the detention order, the petitioner was arrested on July 23, 1973. The petitioner has number filed this petition through jail under article 32 of the Constitution for a writ of habeas companypus.

facts.text: Detention order made on June 1, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: After making the detention order on June 1, 1973 the D.M. sent report to the State Government about his having made the detention order along with the grounds of detention and other necessary particulars.

facts.text: DM sent report to State Government after detention order with grounds and particulars.

anchor.surface_text: After making the detention order on June 1, 1973 the D.M. sent report to the State Government about his having made the detention order along with the grounds of detention and other necessary particulars.

facts.text: State Government approved detention order on June 12, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government approved the detention order oil June 12, 1973. The petitioner at the time of his arrest on July 23, 1973 was served with the order of detention as well as the grounds of detention together with vernacular translation thereof.

facts.text: Petitioner served with detention order, grounds, and vernacular translation on arrest July 23, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner at the time of his arrest on July 23, 1973 was served with the order of detention as well as the grounds of detention together with vernacular translation thereof.

facts.text: Petitioner's case placed before Advisory Board on August 7, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the petitioner was placed before the Advisory Board on August 7, 1973. The same day the State Government received a representation from the petitioner.

facts.text: State Government received representation from petitioner on August 7, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: The same day the State Government received a representation from the petitioner. The said representation after being companysidered was rejected by the State Government on August 8, 1973.

facts.text: State Government rejected petitioner's representation on August 8, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: The said representation after being companysidered was rejected by the State Government on August 8, 1973. The representation was then forwarded to the Advisory Board.

facts.text: Representation forwarded to Advisory Board.

anchor.surface_text: The representation was then forwarded to the Advisory Board. The Advisory Board expressed the opinion on September 25, 1973 that there was sufficient cause for the detention of the petitioner.

facts.text: Advisory Board opined sufficient cause for detention on September 25, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: The Advisory Board expressed the opinion on September 25, 1973 that there was sufficient cause for the detention of the petitioner. On October 1, 1973 the State Government companyfirmed the detention order.

facts.text: State Government confirmed detention order on October 1, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: On October 1, 1973 the State Government companyfirmed the detention order.

facts.text: On 8-5-73 at 04.00 hrs, petitioner with associates stopped rickshaw of Sri Gopal Sharma from Burdwan Railway Station to Curzon Gate, snatched Rs. 20 and valuables on point of dagger.

anchor.surface_text: On 8-5-73 at about 04.00 hrs. you along with your associates stopped the rickshaw of Sri Gopal Sharma on point of dagger while he was companying from Burdwan Railway Station towards Curzon Gate and snatched each Rs. 20/-and other valuables and escaped.

facts.text: Robbery on 8-5-73 created panic amongst local people and disturbed normal avocation of life.

anchor.surface_text: Your companymission of this highway robbery created panic amongst local people and thereby disturbed the numbermal avocation of life in the area.

facts.text: On 15-5-73 at 04.30 hours, petitioner with associates Swapan Singh and others attacked Shri Aditya Mondal, bus conductor on B.C. Road, Burdwan, robbed Rs. 30, wrist watch, valuables on point of open Bhojali.

anchor.surface_text: On 15-5-73 at about 04.30 hours your along with your associates Swapan Singh and others attacked Shri Aditya Mondal, a Bus companyductor on B. C. Road, Burdwan and on the point of an open Bhojali robbed him of each Rs. 30/- one wrist watch and other valuables and forced him to keep silent.

facts.text: Robbery on 15-5-73 terrorised local people, created panic, disturbed flow of life.

anchor.surface_text: Your such act terrorised the local people and created a sense of panic in their minds and as a result flow of life in the area was highly disturbed. Your such acts created a panic in the area and the local people were afraid to companye out of door as usual and their numbermal avocation of life was disturbed.

facts.text: Two cases registered against petitioner for the activities in grounds of detention.

anchor.surface_text: It has further been argued by Mr. Narayana Rao that two cases were registered against the petitioner in respect of the activities mentioned in the grounds of detention.

facts.text: In both cases, final reports submitted and petitioner discharged as witnesses unwilling due to fear.

anchor.surface_text: It would appear from the affidavit of Shri Shyama Charan Chatterjee District Magistrate that in both the cases final reports were submitted and the petitioner was got discharged as the witnesses were unwilling to give evidence against him in open companyrt for fear of their lives.

facts.text: Names of all associates not mentioned in grounds of detention.

anchor.surface_text: Another companytention advanced by Mr. Narayana Rao is that the names of all the associates of the petitioner were number mentioned in the grounds of detention and as such the grounds should be held to be vague.

facts.text: Period of detention not specified by State Government.

anchor.surface_text: Reference has also been made to the fact that the period of the petitioners detention has number been specified by the State Government

facts.text: Court finds activities have direct nexus with maintenance of public order.

anchor.surface_text: The activities attributed to the petitioner, in our opinion, have a direct nexus with the maintenance of public order because they bad the effect of disturbing the even tempo of life of the people in the locality.

facts.text: Grounds of detention not vague.

anchor.surface_text: The grounds of detention in the present case do number suffer from the infirmity of vagueness.

issues.text: Whether the alleged activities for which the petitioner had been detained were germane to public order?

anchor.surface_text: It has been argued by Mr. Narayana Rao, who has appeared amicus curiae on behalf of the petitioner, that the alleged activities for which the petitioner had been detained were number germane to public order. In this connection we find that according to the grounds of detention, the petitioner was being detained because in the opinion of the District Magistrate he was acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order as evidenced by the particulars given below On 8-5-73 at about 04.00

issues.text: Whether the grounds of detention are vague on account of non-mentioning of names of all associates of the petitioner?

anchor.surface_text: The grounds of detention in the present case do number suffer from the infirmity of vagueness. The fact that the names of all the associates of the petitioner were number given in the grounds of detention would number make the grounds to be vague see also Sk. Hasan Ali v. State of West Bengal l  wherein a similar contention on was repelled . It has further been argued by Mr. Narayana Rao that two cases were registered against the petitioner in respect of the activities mentioned in the grounds of detention.

issues.text: Whether there is a legal bar to detention under the Maintenance of Internal Security Act despite registration and discharge in criminal cases for the same activities?

anchor.surface_text: It would appear from the affidavit of Shri Shyama Charan Chatterjee District Magistrate that in both the cases final reports were submitted and the petitioner was got discharged as the witnesses were unwilling to give evidence against him in open court for fear of their lives. In the circumstances there was number legal bar in the way of the District Magistrate in making an order for the detention of the petitioner.

issues.text: Whether the detention order suffers from infirmity for non-specification of the period of detention by the State Government?

anchor.surface_text: Reference has also been made to the fact that the period of the petitioners detention has number been specified by the State Government This fact, in our opinion, does number introduce an infirmity in the detention order. A similar question arose before this Court in Suna Ulla v. State of J. K.  2  while dealing with a detention order under the Jammu Kashmir Preventive Detention Act, 1964.

arguments.claim: Activities have direct nexus with maintenance of public order as they disturbed even tempo of life.

anchor.surface_text: The activities attributed to the petitioner, in our opinion, have a direct nexus with the maintenance of public order because they bad the effect of disturbing the even tempo of life of the people in the locality.

arguments.claim: Activities disturb public order per test: interfere with current of life of community.

anchor.surface_text: The test for determining whether a particular activity affects law and order or whether it impinges upon public order is Does it interfere with the current of life of the community so as to amount to disturbance of public order or does it affect merely an individual leaving the tranquillity of the society undisturbed in which case it would be an activity affecting law and order

arguments.court_reasoning: Applied test from Kanu Biswas; activities disturb public order.

arguments.claim: Sushanta Goswami case distinguishable as no panic or disturbance shown there.

anchor.surface_text: There is, however, nothing to show that in that case the activity of the detenu created panic amongst the local people and thereby disturbed the normal avocation of life in the area.

arguments.claim: Grounds not vague; sufficient particulars for effective representation.

anchor.surface_text: Perusal of the grounds of detention shows that the date, time and place of the incidents were specified. Particulars were also given regarding the nature of the activities of the petitioner.

arguments.claim: No legal bar to detention despite discharge in criminal cases due to witness fear.

anchor.surface_text: It would appear from the affidavit of Shri Shyama Charan Chatterjee District Magistrate that in both the cases final reports were submitted and the petitioner was got discharged as the witnesses were unwilling to give evidence against him in open court for fear of their lives.

arguments.claim: Detaining authority can detain even if no admissible evidence for conviction under IPC/Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the particular act of the detenu which provides the reason for the making of the detention order constitutes an offence under the Indian Penal Code would not prevent the detaining authority from passing the order for detention instead of proceeding against him in a court of law.

arguments.claim: No infirmity in not specifying detention period on confirmation under relevant Act.

anchor.surface_text: This fact, in our opinion, does number introduce an infirmity in the detention order. A similar question arose before this Court in Suna Ulla v. State of J. K.  2  while dealing with a detention order under the Jammu Kashmir Preventive Detention Act, 1964.

holdings.text: The activities attributed to the petitioner have a direct nexus with the maintenance of public order because they had the effect of disturbing the even tempo of life of the people in the locality.

anchor.surface_text: The activities attributed to the petitioner, in our opinion, have a direct nexus with the maintenance of public order because they bad the effect of disturbing the even tempo of life of the people in the locality.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied test distinguishing law and order from public order; robberies terrorised locals, created panic, disturbed normal life.

holdings.text: Keeping this test in view we have no doubt that the activities of the petitioner had the effect of disturbing public order.

anchor.surface_text: Keeping this test in view we have numberdoubt that the activities of the petitioner had the effect of disturbing public order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Activities interfere with current of community life, not merely individual, per Kanu Biswas test.

holdings.text: The grounds of detention in the present case do not suffer from the infirmity of vagueness.

anchor.surface_text: The grounds of detention in the present case do number suffer from the infirmity of vagueness.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dates, times, places, nature specified; sufficient to enable effective representation; non-mention of all associates' names immaterial; cites Sk. Hasan Ali.

holdings.text: There was no legal bar in the way of the District Magistrate in making an order for the detention of the petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: It would appear from the affidavit of Shri Shyama Charan Chatterjee District Magistrate that in both the cases final reports were submitted and the petitioner was got discharged as the witnesses were unwilling to give evidence against him in open companyrt for fear of their lives. In the circumstances there was numberlegal bar in the way of the District Magistrate in making an order for the detention of the petitioner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discharge due to witness fear does not bar detention; preventive detention distinct from prosecution; cites Sasti Satish Chowdhary, Mohd. Salini Khan.

holdings.text: The fact that the particular act constitutes an offence under the Indian Penal Code would not prevent the detaining authority from passing the order for detention instead of proceeding against him in a court of law.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the particular act of the detenu which provides the reason for the making of the detention order constitutes an offence under the Indian Penal Code would not prevent the detaining authority from passing the order for detention instead of proceeding against him in a companyrt of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Detaining authority may act despite insufficient evidence for conviction; incident germane to detention object.

holdings.text: This fact does not introduce an infirmity in the detention order.

anchor.surface_text: This fact, in our opinion, does number introduce an infirmity in the detention order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No statutory requirement under section 12 to specify period on confirmation; Government may continue for period it thinks fit up to two years; cites Suna Ulla.

precedents.citation: Kanu Biswas v. State of West Bengal 1

anchor.surface_text: order see Kanu Biswas v. State of West Bengal 1 . Keeping this test in view we have no doubt that the activities of the petitioner had the effect of disturbing public order.

precedents.case_name: Kanu Biswas v. State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Test for determining if activity affects law and order or public order: interferes with current of life of community vs merely individual

anchor.surface_text: Reference has been made by Mr. Narayana Rao to the case of In Re Sushanta Goswami Ors.  2  wherein this Court directed the release of a detenu named Ram Kamal Dhar inspite of the fact that he along with his associates was alleged to have snatched a wrist watch from a person at the point of dagger.

precedents.cited_proposition: Release of detenu despite allegation of snatching wrist watch at dagger point

precedents.citation: Sk. Hasan Ali v. State of West Bengal l

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the names of all the associates of the petitioner were not given in the grounds of detention would not make the grounds to be vague see also Sk. Hasan Ali v. State of West Bengal l  wherein a similar contention on was repelled .

precedents.case_name: Sk. Hasan Ali v. State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Grounds of detention not vague for not naming all associates; similar contention repelled

precedents.citation: Sasti Satish Chowdhary v. Chowdhary v. State of West Bengal 2

anchor.surface_text: A similar argument was advanced on behalf of the detenu in the case of Sasti Satish Chowdhary v. Chowdhary v. State of West Bengal 2  and it was repelled in the following words It is always open to the detaining authority to pass an order for the detention of a person if the grounds of detention are germane to the object for which a detention order can legally be made.

precedents.case_name: Sasti Satish Chowdhary v. State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Detention possible even if activity is an offence under IPC, even if discharged, if germane and evidence insufficient for conviction
precedents.cited_holding: It is always open to the detaining authority to pass an order for the detention of a person if the grounds of detention are germane to the object for which a detention order can legally be made. The fact that the particular act... constitutes an offence under the Indian Penal Code would not prevent the detaining authority from passing the order for detention...

precedents.citation: Mohd. Salini Khan v. Shri C. C. Bose Anr.  Writ petition No. 435 of 1971 decided on April 25, 1972

anchor.surface_text: It was recently observed by this Court in the case of Mohd. Salini Khan v. Shri C. C. Bose Anr.  Writ petition No. 435 of 1971 decided on April 25, 1972  that from the mere fact that a detenu was discharged in a criminal case relating to an incident by a magistrate, it could not be said that the detention order on the basis of that incident was incompetent, not could it be inferred that it was without basis or mala fide.

precedents.case_name: Mohd. Salini Khan v. Shri C. C. Bose Anr.
precedents.cited_proposition: Discharge in criminal case does not make detention order incompetent or imply lack of basis or mala fides
precedents.cited_holding: from the mere fact that a detenu was discharged in a criminal case relating to an incident by a magistrate, it could not be said that the detention order on the basis of that incident was incompetent, not could it be inferred that it was without basis or mala fide.

precedents.citation: Sahib Singh Duggal v. Union of India 1

anchor.surface_text: Reliance in this connection was placed upon the case of Sahib Singh Duggal v. Union of India 1 , Reference has also been made to the fact that the period of the petitioners detention has not been specified by the State Government

precedents.case_name: Sahib Singh Duggal v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Support for proposition that discharge does not invalidate detention

precedents.citation: Suna Ulla v. State of J. K.  2

anchor.surface_text: A similar question arose before this Court in Suna Ulla v. State of J. K.  2  while dealing with a detention order under the Jammu Kashmir Preventive Detention Act, 1964. It was held by this Court that it is difficult to infer from the language of section 12 of the Jammu and Kashmir Preventive Detention Act that the State Government while confirming the detention order should also specify the period of detention.

precedents.case_name: Suna Ulla v. State of J. K.
precedents.cited_proposition: No requirement for government to specify period of detention when confirming detention order
precedents.cited_holding: it is difficult to infer from the language of section 12... that the State Government while confirming the detention order should also specify the period of detention.
